lines.text: The Duke of Norfolke, sprightfully and bold,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Stayes but the summons of the Appealants Trumpet.

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: Why then the Champions, are prepar'd, and stay

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: For nothing but his Maiesties approach.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Marshall, demand of yonder Champion

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The cause of his arriuall heere in Armes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Aske him his name, and orderly proceed

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To sweare him in the iustice of his cause.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: In Gods name, and the Kings say who y u art,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Against what man thou com'st, and what's thy quarrell,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Speake truly on thy knighthood, and thine oath,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: As so defend thee heauen, and thy valour.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: My name is {% italic: Mowbray %}, Duke of Norfolk,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Who hither comes engaged by my oath

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: (Which heauen defend a knight should violate)

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Both to defend my loyalty and truth,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: To God, my King, and his succeeding issue,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Against the Duke of Herford, that appeales me:

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: And by the grace of God, and this mine arme,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: To proue him (in defending of my selfe)

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: A Traitor to my God, my King, and me,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: And as I truly fight, defend me heauen.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Marshall: Aske yonder Knight in Armes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Both who he is, and why he commeth hither,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thus placed in habiliments of warre:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And formerly according to our Law

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Depose him in the iustice of his cause.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: What is thy name? and wherfore comst y u hither

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Before King {% italic: Richard %} in his Royall Lists?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Against whom com'st thou? and what's thy quarrell?

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Speake like a true Knight, so defend thee heauen.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: {% italic: Harry %} of Herford, Lancaster, and Derbie,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Am I: who ready heere do stand in Armes,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: To proue by heauens grace, and my bodies valour,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: In Lists, on {% italic: Thomas Mowbray %} Duke of Norfolke,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: That he's a Traitor foule, and dangerous,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: To God of heauen, King {% italic: Richard %}, and to me,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: And as I truly fight, defend me heauen.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: On paine of death, no person be so bold,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Or daring hardie as to touch the Listes,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Except the Marshall, and such Officers

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Appointed to direct these faire designes.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Lord Marshall, let me kisse my Soueraigns hand,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: And bow my knee before his Maiestie:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: For {% italic: Mowbray %} and my selfe are like two men,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: That vow a long and weary pilgrimage,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Then let vs take a ceremonious leaue

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: And louing farwell of our seuerall friends.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: The Appealant in all duty greets your Highnes,

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: And craues to kisse your hand, and take his leaue.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: We will descend, and fold him in our armes.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Cosin of Herford, as they cause is iust,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So be thy fortune in this Royall fight:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Farewell, my blood, which if to day thou shead,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Lament we may, but not reuenge thee dead.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Oh let no noble eye prophane a teare

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: For me, if I be gor'd with {% italic: Mowbrayes %} speare:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: As confident, as is the Falcons flight

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Against a bird, do I with {% italic: Mowbray %} fight.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: My louing Lord, I take my leaue of you,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Of you (my Noble Cosin) Lord {% italic: Aumerle %};

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Not sicke, although I haue to do with death,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: But lustie, yong, and cheerely drawing breath.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Loe, as at English Feasts, so I regreete

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: The daintiest last, to make the end most sweet.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Oh thou the earthy author of my blood,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Whose youthfull spirit in me regenerate,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Doth with a two‑fold rigor lift mee vp

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To reach at victory aboue my head,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Adde proofe vnto mine Armour with thy prayres,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And with thy blessings steele my Lances point,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: That it may enter {% italic: Mowbrayes %} waxen Coate,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And furnish new the name of {% italic: Iohn a Gaunt %},

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Euen in the lusty hauiour of his sonne.

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Heauen in thy good cause make thee prosp'rous

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Be swift like lightning in the execution,

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: And let thy blowes doubly redoubled,

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Fall like amazing thunder on the Caske

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Of thy amaz'd pernicious enemy.

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Rouze vp thy youthfull blood, be valiant, and liue.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Mine innocence, and {% italic: George %} to thriue.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: How euer heauen or fortune cast my lot,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: There liues, or dies, tgrue to Kings {% italic: Richards %} Throne,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: A loyall, iust, and vpright Gentleman:

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Neuer did Captiue with a freer heart,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Cast off his chaines of bondage, and embrace

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: His golden vncontroul'd enfranchisement,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: More then my dancing soule doth celebrate

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: This Feast of Battell, with mine Aduersarie.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Most mighty Liege, and my companion Peeres,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Take from my mouth, the wish of happy yeares,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: As gentle, and as iocond, as to iest,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Go I to fight: Truth, hath a quiet brest.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Farewell, my Lord, securely I espy

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vertue with Valour, couched in thine eye:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Order the trial Marshall, and begin.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: {% italic: Harrie %} of {% italic: Herford, Lancaster %}, and {% italic: Derby %},

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Receiue thy Launce, and heauen defend thy right.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Strong as a towre in hope, I cry Amen.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Go beare this Lance to {% italic: Thomas %} of Norfolke.

lines.speaker: 1. Har.
lines.text: {% italic: Harry %} of {% italic: Herford %}, {% italic: Lancaster %}, and {% italic: Derbie %},

lines.speaker: 1. Har.
lines.text: Stands heere for God, his Soueraigne, and himselfe,

lines.speaker: 1. Har.
lines.text: On paine to be found false, and recreant,

lines.speaker: 1. Har.
lines.text: To proue the Duke of Norfolke, {% italic: Thomas Mowbray %},

lines.speaker: 1. Har.
lines.text: A Traitor to his God, his King, and him,

lines.speaker: 1. Har.
lines.text: And dares him to set forwards to the fight.

lines.speaker: 2. Har.
lines.text: Here standeth {% italic: Mowbray %} Duke of Norfolk

lines.speaker: 2. Har.
lines.text: On paine to be found false and recreant,

lines.speaker: 2. Har.
lines.text: Both to defend himselfe, and to approue

lines.speaker: 2. Har.
lines.text: {% italic: Henry %} of {% italic: Herford, Lancaster %}, and {% italic: Derby %},

lines.speaker: 2. Har.
lines.text: To God, his Soueraigne, and to him disloyall:

lines.speaker: 2. Har.
lines.text: Couragiously, and with a free desire

lines.speaker: 2. Har.
lines.text: Attending but the signall to begin.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Sound Trumpets, and set forward Combatants:

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: Stay, the King hath throwne his Warder downe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let them lay by their Helmets & their Speares,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And both returne backe to their Chaires againe:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Withdraw with vs, and let the Trumpets sound,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: While we returne these Dukes what we decree.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Draw neere and lift

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What with our Councell we haue done.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For that our kingdomes earth should not be soyld

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With that deere blood which it hath fostered,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And for our eyes do hate the dire aspect

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of ciuill wounds plowgh'd vp with neighbors swords,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which so rouz'd up with boystrous vntun'd drummes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With harsh resounding Trumpets dreadfull bray,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And grating shocke of wrathfull yron Armes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Might from our quiet Confines fright faire peace,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And make vs wade euen in our kindreds blood:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Therefore, we banish you our Territories.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: You Cosin Herford, vpon paine of death,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Till twice liue Summers haue enrich'd our fields,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall not regreet our faire dominions,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But treade the stranger pathes of banishment.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Your will be done: This must my comfort be,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: That Sun that warmes you heere, shall shine on me:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: And those his golden beames to you heere lent,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Shall point on me, and gild my banishment.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Norfolke: for thee remaines a heauier dombe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which I with some vnwillingnesse pronounce,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The slye slow houres shall not determinate

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The datelesse limit of thy deere exile:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The hopelesse word, of Neuer to returne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Breath I against thee, vpon paine of life.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: A heauy sentence, my most Soueraigne Liege,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: And all vnlook'd for from your Highnesse mouth:

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: A deerer merit, not so deepe a maime,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: As to be cast forth in the common ayre

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Haue I deserued at your Highnesse hands.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: The Language I haue learn'd these forty yeares

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: (My natiue English) now I must forgo,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: And now my tongues use is to me no more,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Then an vnstringed Vyall, or a Harpe,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Or like a cunning Instrument cas'd vp,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Or being open, put into his hands

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: That knowes no touch to tune the harmony.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Within my mouth you haue engaol'd my tongue,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Doubly percullist with my teeth and lippes,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: And dull, vnfeeling, barren ignorance,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Is made my Gaoler to attend on me:

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: I am too old to fawne vpon a Nurse,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Too farre in yeeres to be a pupill now:

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: What is thy sentence then, but speechlesse death,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Which robs my tongue from breathing natiue breath?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: It boots thee not to be compassionate,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: After our sentence, plaining comes too late.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Then thus I turne me from my countries light

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: To dwell in solemne shades of endlesse night.

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Returne againe, and take an oath with thee,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Lay on our Royall sword, your banisht hands;

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Sweare by the duty that you owe to heauen

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: (Our part therein we banish with your selues)

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: To keepe the Oath that we administer:

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: You neuer shall (so helpe you Truth, and Heauen)

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Embrace each others loue in banishment,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Nor euer looke vpon each others face,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Nor euer write, regreete, or reconcile

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: This lowring tempest of your home‑bred hate,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Nor euer by aduised purpose meete,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: To plot, contriue, or complot any ill,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: 'Gainst Vs, our State, our Subiects, or our Land.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I sweare.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: And I, to keepe all this.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Norfolke, so fare, as to mine enemie,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: By this time (had the King permitted vs)

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: One of our soules had wandred in the ayre,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Banish'd this fraile sepulchre of our flesh,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: As now our flesh is banish'd from this Land.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Confesse thy Treasons, ere thou flye this Realme,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Since thou hast farre to go, beare not along

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: The clogging burthen of a guilty soule.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: No {% italic: Bullingbroke: %} If euer I were Traitor,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: My name be blotted from the booke of Life,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: And I from heauen banish'd, as from hence:

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: But what thou art, heauen, thou, and I do know,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: And all too soone (I feare) the King shall rue.

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Farewell (my Liege) now no way can I stray,

lines.speaker: Mow.
lines.text: Saue backe to England, all the worlds my way.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vncle, euen in the glasses of thine eyes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I see thy greeued heart: thy sad aspect,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Hath from the number of his banish'd yeares

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Pluck'd foure away: Six frozen Winters spent,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Returne with welcome home, from banishment.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: How long a time lyes in one little word:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Foure lagging Winters, and foure wanton springs

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: End in a word, such is the breath of Kings.

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: I thanke my Liege, that in regard of me

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: He shortens foure years of my sonnes exile:

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: But little vantage shall I reape thereby.

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: For ere the sixe yeares that he hath to spend

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Can change their Moones, and bring their times about,

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: My oyle‑dride Lampe, and time‑bewasted light

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Shall be extinct with age, and endlesse night:

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: My inch of Taper, will be burnt, and done,

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: And blindfold death, not let me see my sonne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Why Vncle, thou hast many yeeres to liue.

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: But not a minute (King) that thou canst giue;

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Shorten my dayes thou canst with sudden sorow,

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: And plucke nights from me, but not lend a morrow:

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Thou canst helpe time to furrow me with age,

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: But stop no wrinkle in his pilgrimage:

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Thy word is currant with him, for my death,

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: But dead, thy kingdome cannot buy my breath.

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Thy sonne is banish'd vpon good aduice,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Where to thy tongue a party‑verdict gaue,

lines.speaker: Ric.
lines.text: Why at our Iustice seem'st thou then to lowre?

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: Things sweet to tast, proue in digestion sowre:

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: You vrg'd me as a Iudge, but I had rather

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: you would haue bid me argue like a Father.

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: Alas, I look'd when some of you should say,

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: I was too strict to make mine owne away:

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: But you gaue leaue to my vnwilling tong,

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: Against my will, to do my selfe this wrong.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Cosine farewell: and Vncle bid him so:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Six yeares we banish him, and he shall go.

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: Confine farewell what presence must not know

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: From where you do remaine, let paper show.

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: My Lord, no leaue take I, for I will ride

lines.speaker: Mar.
lines.text: As farre as land will let me, by your side.

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: Oh to what purpose dost thou hord thy words,

lines.speaker: Gaunt.
lines.text: That thou returnst no greeting to thy friends?

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I haue too few to take my leaue of you,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: When the tongues office should be prodigall,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To breath th'abundant dolour of the heart.

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: Thy greefe is but thy absence for a time.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Ioy absent, greefe is present for that time.

lines.speaker: Gan.
lines.text: What is sixe Winters, they are quickely gone?

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: To men in ioy, but greefe makes one houre ten.

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: Call it a trauell that thou tak'st for pleasure.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: My heart will sigh, when I miscall it so,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Which findes it an inforced Pilgrimage.

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: The sullen passage of thy weary steppes

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: Esteeme a soyle, wherein thou art to set

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: The precious Iewell of thy home returne.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Oh who can hold a fire in his hand

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: By thinking on the froste {% italic: Caucasus %}?

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Or cloy the hungry edge of appetite,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: by bare imagination of a Feast?

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Or Wallow naked in December snow

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: by thinking on fantasticke summers heate?

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Oh no, the apprehension of the good

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Giues but the greater feeling to the worse:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Fell sorrowes tooth, doth euer ranckle more

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Then when it bites, but lanceth not the sore.

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: Come, come (my son) Ile bring thee on thy way

lines.speaker: Gau.
lines.text: Had I thy youth, and cause, I would not stay.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Then Englands ground farewell: sweet soil adieu,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: My Mother, and my Nurse, which beares me yet:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Where ere I wander, boast of this I can,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Though banish'd, yet a true‑borne Englishman.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: We did obserue. Cosine {% italic: Aumerle %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How far brought you high Herford on his way?

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: I brought high Herford (if you call him so)

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: but to the next high way, and there I left him.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And say, what store of parting tears were shed?

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Faith none for me: except the Northeast wind

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Which then grew bitterly against our face,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Awak'd the sleepie rhewme, and so by chance

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Did grace our hollow parting with a teare.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What said our Cosin when you parted with him?

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: Farewell: and for my hart disdained y t my tongue

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: Should so prophane the word, that taught me craft

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: To counterfeit oppression of such greefe,

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: That word seem'd buried in my sorrowes graue.

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: Marry, would the word Farwell, haue lengthen'd houres,

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: And added yeeres to his short banishment,

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: He should haue had a volume of Farwels,

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: but since it would not, he had none of me.

lines.text: Meerely in hate 'gainst any of vs all,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: That will the King seuerely prosecute

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: 'Gainst vs, our liues, our children, and our heires.

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: The Commons hath he pil'd with greeuous taxes

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: And quite lost their hearts: the Nobles hath he finde

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.

lines.speaker: Wil.
lines.text: And daily new exactions are deuis'd,

lines.speaker: Wil.
lines.text: As blankes, beneuolences, and I wo not what:

lines.speaker: Wil.
lines.text: But what o'Gods name doth become of this?

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Wars hath not wasted it, for war'd he hath not.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: But basely yielded vpon comprimize,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: That which his Ancestors atchieu'd with blowes:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: More hath he spent in peace, then they in warres.

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: The Earle of Wiltshire hath the realme in Farme.

lines.speaker: Wil.
lines.text: The Kings growne bankrupt like a broken man.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Reproach and dissolution hangeth ouer him.

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: He hath not monie for these Irish warres:

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: (His burthenous taxations notwithstanding)

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: But by the robbing of the banish'd Duke.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: His noble Kinsman, most degenerate King:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: But Lords, we heare this fearefull tempest sing,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Yet seeke no shelter to auoid the storme:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: We see the winde sit sore vpon our sailes,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: And yet we strike not, but securely perish

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: We see the very wracke that we must suffer,

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: And vnauoyded is the danger now

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: For suffering so the causes of our wracke.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Not so: euen through the hollow eyes of death,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: I spie life peering: but I dare not say

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: How neere the tidings of our comfort is.

lines.speaker: Wil.
lines.text: Nay let vs share thy thoughts, as thou dost ours

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: Be confident to speake Northumberland,

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: We three, are but thy selfe, and speaking so,

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: Thy words are but as thoughts, therefore be bold.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Then thus: I haue from Port {% italic: le Blan %}

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: A Bay in {% italic: Britaine %}, receiu'd intelligence,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: That {% italic: Harry %} Duke of {% italic: Herford, Rainald %} Lord {% italic: Cobham %},

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: That late broke from the Duke of {% italic: Exeter %},

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: His brother Archbishop, late of {% italic: Canterbury %},

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Thomas Erpingham %}, Sir {% italic: Iohn Rainston %},

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Sir {% italic: Iohn Norberie %}, Sir {% italic: Robert Waterton %}, & {% italic: Francis Quoint %},

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: All these well furnish'd by the Duke of {% italic: Britaine %},

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: With eight tall ships, three thousand men of warre

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Are making hither with all due expedience,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: And shortly meane to touch our Northerne shore:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: The first departing of the King for Ireland.

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: If then we shall shake off our slauish yoake,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Impe out our drooping Countries broken wing,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Redeeme from broaking pawne the blemish'd Crowne,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Wipe off the dust that hides our Scepters gilt,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: And make high Maiestie looke like it selfe,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Away with me in poste to {% italic: Rauenspurgh %},

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: But if you faint, as fearing to do so,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Stay, and be secret, and my selfe will go.

lines.speaker: Ros.
lines.text: To horse, to horse, vrge doubts to them y t feare.

lines.speaker: Wil.
lines.text: Hold out my horse, and I will first be there.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Madam, your Maiesty is too much sad,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: You promis'd when you parted with the King,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: To lay aside selfe‑harming heauinesse,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: And entertaine a cheerefull disposition.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To please the King, I did: to please my selfe

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I cannot do it: yet I know no cause

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Why I should welcome such a guest as greefe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Saue bidding farewell to so sweet a guest

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: As my sweet {% italic: Richard %}; yet againe me thinkes,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Some vnborne sorrow, ripe in fortunes wombe

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Is comming towards me, and my inward soule

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: With nothing trembles, at something it greeues,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: More then with parting from my Lord the King.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Each substance of a greefe hath twenty shadows

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Which shewes like greefe it selfe, but is not so:

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: For sorrowes eye, glazed with blinding teares,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Diuides one thing intire, to many obiects,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Like perspectiues, which rightly gaz'd vpon

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Shew nothing but confusion, ey'd awry,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Distinguish forme: so your sweet Maiestie

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Looking awry vpon your Lords departure,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Finde shapes of greefe, more then himselfe to waile,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Which look'd on as it is, is naught but shadowes

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Of what it is not: then thrice‑gracious Queene,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: More then your Lords departure weep not, more's not ( seene;

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrowes eie,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Which for things true, weepe things imaginary.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: It may be so: but yet my inward soule

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Perswades me it is otherwise: how ere it be,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I cannot but be sad: so heauy sad,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: As though on thinking on no thought I thinke,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Makes me with heauy nothing faint and shrinke.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: 'Tis nothing but conceit (my gracious Lady.)

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: 'Tis nothing lesse: conceit is still deriu'd

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: From some fore‑father greefe, mine is not so,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: For nothing hath begot my something greefe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Or something, hath the nothing that I greeue,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: 'Tis in reuersion that I do possesse,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But what it is, that is not yet knowne, what

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I cannot name, 'tis namelesse woe I wot.

lines.speaker: Gree.
lines.text: Heauen saue your Maiesty, and wel met Gentle­ ( men:

lines.speaker: Gree.
lines.text: I hope the King is not yet shipt for Ireland.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Why hop'st thou so? Tis better hope he is:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: For his designes craue hast, his hast good hope,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Then wherefore dost thou hope he is not shipt?

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: That he our hope, might haue retyr'd his power,

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: and driuen into dispaire an enemies hope,

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Who strongly hath set footing in this Land.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: The banish'd {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} repeales himselfe,

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: And with vp‑lifted Armes is safe arriu'd

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: At {% italic: Rauenspurg %}.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Now God in heauen forbid.

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: O Madam 'tis too true: and that is worse,

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: The Northumberland, his yong sonne {% italic: Henrie Percie %},

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: The Lords of {% italic: Rosse, Beaumo %}, and {% italic: Willoughby %},

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: With all their powrefull friends are fled to him.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Why haue you not proclaim'd Northumberland

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: And the rest of the reuolted faction, Traitors?

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: We haue: whereupon the Earle of Worcester

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Hath broke his staffe, resign'd his Stewardship,

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: And al the houshold seruants fled with him to {% italic: Bullinbrook %}

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: So {% italic: Greene %}, thou art the midwife of my woe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And {% italic: Bullinbrooke %} my sorrowes dismall heyre:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Now hath my soule brought forth her prodegie,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And I a gasping new deliuered mother,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Haue woe to woe, sorrow to sorrow ioyn'd.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Dispaire not Madam.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Who shall hinder me?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I will dispaire, and be at enmitie

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: With couzening hope; he is a Flatterer,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: A Parasite, a keeper backe of death,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Who gently would dissolue the bands of life,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Which false hopes linger in extremity.

lines.speaker: Gre.
lines.text: Heere comes the Duke of Yorke.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: With signes of warre about his aged necke,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Oh full of carefull businesse are his lookes:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Vncle, for heauens sake speake comfortable words:

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Comfort's in heauen, and we are on the earth,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Where nothing liues but crosses, care and greefe:

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Your husband he is gone to saue farre off,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Whilst others come to make him loose at home:

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Heere am I left to vnder‑prop his Land,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Who weake with age, cannot support my selfe:

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Now comes the sicke houre that his surfet made,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Now shall he try his friends that flattered him.

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: My Lord, your sonne was gone before I came.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: He was: why so: go all which way it will:

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: The Nobles they are fled, the Commons they are cold,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: And will I feare reuolt on Herfords side.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Sirra, get thee to Plashie to my sister Gloster,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Bid her send me presently a thousand pound,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Hold, take my Ring.

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: My Lord, I had forgot

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: To tell your Lordship, to day I came by, and call'd there,

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: But I shall greeue you to report the rest.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: What is't knaue?

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: An houre before I came, the Dutchesse di'de.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Heau'n for his mercy, what a tide of woes

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Come rushing on this wofull Land at once?

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: I know not what to do: I would to heauen

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: (So my vntruth had not prouok'd him to it)

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: The King had cut off my head with my brothers.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: What, are there postes dispatcht for Ireland?

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: How shall we do for money for these warres?

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Come sister (Cozen I would say) pray pardon me.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Go fellow, get thee home, p oouide some Carts,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: And bring away the Armour that is there.

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Gentlemen, will you muster men?

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: If I know how, or which way to order these affaires

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Thus disorderly thrust into my hands,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Neuer beleeue me. Both are my kinsmen,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Th'one is my Soueraigne, whom both my oath

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: And dutie bids defend: th'other againe

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Is my kinsman, whom the King hath wrong'd,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Whom conscience, and my kindred bids to right:

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Well, somewhat we must do: Come Cozen,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: Ile dispose of you. Gentlemen, go muster vp your men,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: And meet me presently at Barkley Castle:

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: I should to Plashy too: but time will not permit,

lines.speaker: Yor.
lines.text: All is vneuen, and euery thing is left at six and seuen.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: The winde sits faire for newes to go to Ireland,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: But none returnes: For vs to leuy power

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Proportionable to th'enemy, is all impossible.

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: Besides our nee renesse to the King in loue,

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: Is neere the hate of those loue not the King.

lines.speaker: Ba.
lines.text: And that's the wauering Commons, for their loue

lines.speaker: Ba.
lines.text: Lies in their purses, and who so empties them,

lines.speaker: Ba.
lines.text: By so much fils their hearts with deadly hate.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Wherein the king stands generally condemn'd

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: If iudgement lye in them, then so do we,

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: Because we haue beene euer neere the King.

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: Well: I will for refuge straight to Bristoll Castle,

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: The Earle of Wiltshire is alreadie there.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Thither will I with you, for little office

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Will the hatefull Commons performe for vs,

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Except like Curres, to teare vs all in peeces:

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Will you go along with vs?

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: No, I will to Ireland to his Maistie:

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: Farewell, if hearts presages be not vaine,

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: We three here part, that neu'r shall meete againe.

lines.speaker: Bu.
lines.text: That's as Yorke thriues to beate back {% italic: Bullinbroke %}

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: Alas poore Duke, the taske he vndertakes

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: Is numbring sands, and drinking Oceans drie,

lines.speaker: Gr.
lines.text: Where one on his side fights, thousands will flye.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Farewell a once, for once, for all, and euer.

lines.speaker: Bush.
lines.text: Well, we may meete againe.

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: I feare me neuer.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: How farre is it my Lord to Berkley now?

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Beleeue me noble Lord,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: I am a stranger heere in Gloustershire,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: These high wilde hilles, and rough vneeuen waies,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Drawes out our miles, and makes them wearisome:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: And yet our faire discourse hath beene as sugar,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Making the hard way sweet and delectable:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: But I bethinke me, what a wearie way

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: From Rauenspurgh to Cottshold will be found,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: In {% italic: Rosse %} and {% italic: Willoughby %}, wanting your companie,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Which I protest hath very much beguild

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: The tediousnesse, and processe of my trauell:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: But theirs is sweetned with the hope to haue

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: The present benefit that I possesse:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: And hope to ioy, is little lesse in ioy,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Then hope enioy'd: By this, the wearie Lords

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: Shall make their way seeme short, as mine hath done,

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: By sight of what I haue, your Noble Companie.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Of much lesse value is my Companie,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Then your good words: but who comes here?

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: It is my Sonne, young {% italic: Harry Percie %},

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Sent from my Brother {% italic: Worcester: %} Whence soeuer.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: {% italic: Harry %}, how fares your Vnckle?

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: I had thought, my Lord, to haue learn'd his

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Why, is he not with the Queene?

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: No, my good Lord, he hath forsook the Court,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: Broken his Staffe of Office, and disperst

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: The Household of the King.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: What was his reason?

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: He was not so resolu'd, when we last spake together.

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: Because your Lordship was proclaimed Traitor.

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: But hee, my Lord, is gone to Rauenspurgh,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: To offer seruice to the Duke of Hereford,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: And sent me ouer by Barkely, to discouer

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: What power the Duke of Yorke had leuied there,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: Then with direction to repaire to Rauenspurgh.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Haue you forgot the Duke of Hereford (Boy.)

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: No, my good Lord; for that is not forgot

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: Which ne're I did remember: to my knowledge,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: I neuer in my life did looke on him.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Then learne to know him now: this is the

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: My gracious Lord, I tender you my seruice,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: Such as it is, being tender, raw, and young,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: Which elder dayes shall ripen, and confirme

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: To more approued seruice, and desert.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I thanke thee gentle {% italic: Percie %}, and be sure

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I count my selfe in nothing else so happy,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: As in a Soule remembring my good Friends:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And as my Fortune ripens with thy Loue,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: It shall be still thy true Loues recompence,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: My Heart this Couenant makes, my Hand thus seales it.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: How farre is it to Barkely? and what stirre

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Keepes good old {% italic: Yorke %} there, with his Men of Warre?

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: There stands the Castle, by yond tuft of Trees,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: Mann'd with three hundred men, as I haue heard,

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: And in it are the Lords of {% italic: Yorke, Barkely %}, and {% italic: Seymor %},

lines.speaker: Percie.
lines.text: None else of Name, and noble estimate.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Here come the Lords of {% italic: Rosse %} and {% italic: Willoughby %},

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Bloody with spurring, fierie red with haste.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Welcome my Lords, I wot your loue pursues

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: A banisht Traytor; all my Treasurie

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Is yet but vnfelt thankes, which more enrich'd,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Shall be your loue, and labours recompence.

lines.speaker: Ross.
lines.text: Your presence makes vs rich, most Noble Lord.

lines.speaker: Willo.
lines.text: And farre surmounts our labour to attaine it.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Euermore thankes, th'Exchequer of the poore,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Which till my infant‑fortune comes to yeeres,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Stands for my Bountie: but who comes here ?

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: It is my Lord of Barkely, as I ghesse.

lines.speaker: Bark.
lines.text: My Lord of Hereford, my Message is to you.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: My Lord, my Answere is to {% italic: Lancaster %},

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And I am come to seeke that Name in England,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And I must finde that Title in your Tongue,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Before I make reply to aught you say.

lines.speaker: Bark.
lines.text: Mistake me not, my Lord, 'tis not my meaning

lines.speaker: Bark.
lines.text: To raze one Title of your Honor out.

lines.speaker: Bark.
lines.text: To you, my Lord, I come (what Lord you will)

lines.speaker: Bark.
lines.text: From the most glorious of this Land,

lines.speaker: Bark.
lines.text: The Duke of Yorke, to know what pricks you on

lines.speaker: Bark.
lines.text: To take aduantage of the absent time,

lines.speaker: Bark.
lines.text: And fright our Natiue Peace with selfe‑borne Armes.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I shall not need transport my words by you,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Here comes his Grace in Person. My Noble Vnckle.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Shew me thy humble heart, and not thy knee,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Whose dutie is deceiuable, and false.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: My gracious Vnckle.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Tut, tut, Grace me no Grace, nor Vnckle me,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: I am no Traytors Vnckle, and that word Grace,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: In an vngracious mouth, is but prophane.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Why haue these banish'd, and forbidden Legges,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Dar'd once to touch a Dust of Englands Ground?

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: But more then why, why haue they dar'd to march

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: So many miles vpon her peacefull Bosome,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Frighting her pale‑fac'd Villages with Warre,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: And ostentation of despised Armes?

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Com'st thou because th'anoynted King is hence?

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Why foolish Boy, the King is left behind,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: And in my loyall Bosome lyes his power.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Were I but now the Lord of such hot youth,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: As when braue {% italic: Gaunt %}, thy Father, and my selfe

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Rescued the {% italic: Black Prince %}, that yong {% italic: Mars %} of men,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: From forth the Rankes of many thousand French:

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Oh then, how quickly should this Arme of mine,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Now Prisoner to the Palsie, chastise thee,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: And minister correction to thy Fault.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: My gracious Vnckle, let me know my Fault,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: On what Condition stands it, and wherein?

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Euen in Condition of the worst degree,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: In grosse Rebellion, and detested Treason:

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Before th'expiration of thy time,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: In brauing Armes against thy Soueraigne.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: As I was banish'd, I was banish'd {% italic: Hereford %},

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: But as I come, I come for {% italic: Lancaster %}.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And Noble Vnckle, I beseech your Grace

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Looke on my Wrongs with an indifferent eye:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: You are my Father, for me thinkes in you

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I see old {% italic: Gaunt %} aliue. Oh then my Father,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Will you permit, that I shall stand condemn'd

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: A wandring Vagabond; my Rights and Royalties

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Pluckt from my armes perforce, and giuen away

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To vpstart Vnthrifts? Wherefore was I borne?

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: If that my Cousin King, be King of England,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: It must be graunted, I am Duke of Lancaster.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: You haue a Sonne, {% italic: Aumerle %}, my Noble Kinsman,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Had you first died, and he beene thus trod downe,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: He should haue found his Vnckle {% italic: Gaunt %} a Father,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To rowze his Wrongs, and chase them to the bay.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I am denyde to sue my Liuerie here,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And yet my Letters Patents giue me leaue:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: My Fathers goods are all distraynd, and sold,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And these, and all, are all amisse imployd.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: What would you haue me doe? I am a Subiect,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And challenge Law: Attorneyes are deny'd me:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And therefore personally I lay my claime

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To my Inheritance of free Discent.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: The Noble Duke hath been too much abus'd.

lines.speaker: Ross.
lines.text: It stands your Grace vpon, to doe him right.

lines.speaker: Willo.
lines.text: Base men by his endowments are made great.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: My Lords of England, let me tell you this,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: I haue had feeling of my Cosens Wrongs,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: And labour'd all I could to doe him right:

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: But in this kind, to come in brauing Armes,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Be his owne Caruer, and cut out his way,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: To find out Right with Wrongs, it may not be;

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: And you that doe abett him in this kind,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Cherish Rebellion, and are Rebels all.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: The Noble Duke hath sworne his comming is

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: But for his owne: and for the right of that,

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Wee all haue strongly sworne to giue him ayd,

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: And let him neu'r see Ioy, that breakes that Oath.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Well, well, I see the issue of these Armes,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: I cannot mend it, I must needs confesse,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Because my power is weake, and all ill left:

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: But if I could, by him that gaue me life,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: I would attach you all, and make you stoope

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Vnto the Soueraigne Mercy of the King.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: But since I cannot, be it knowne to you,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: I doe remaine as Neuter. So fare you well,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Vnlesse you please to enter in the Castle,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: And there repose you for this Night.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: An offer Vnckle, that wee will accept:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: But wee must winne your Grace to goe with vs

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To Bristow Castle, which they say is held

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: By {% italic: Bushie, Bagot %}, and ther Complices,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: The Caterpillers of the Commonwealth,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Which I haue sworne to weed, and plucke away.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: It may be I will go with you: but yet Ile pawse,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: For I am loth to breake our Countries Lawes:

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Nor Friends, nor Foes, to me welcome you are,

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: Things past redresse, are now with me past care.

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: My Lord of Salisbury, we haue stayd ten dayes,

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: And hardly kept our Countreymen together,

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: And yet we heare no tidings from the King;

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: Therefore we will disperse our selues: farewell.

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: Stay yet another day, thou trustie Welchman,

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: The King reposeth all his confidence in thee.

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: 'Tis thought the King is dead, we will not stay;

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: And Meteors fright the fixed Starres of Heauen;

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: The pale‑fac'd Moone lookes bloody on the Earth,

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: And leane‑look'd Prophets whisper fearefull change;

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: Rich men looke sad, and Ruffians dance and leape,

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: The one in feare, to loose what they enioy,

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: The other to enioy by Rage, and Warre:

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: These signes fore‑run the death of Kings.

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: Farewell, our Countreymen are gone and fled,

lines.speaker: Capt.
lines.text: As well assur'd {% italic: Richard %} their King is dead.

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: Ah {% italic: Richard %}, with eyes of heauie mind,

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: I see thy Glory, like a shooting Starre,

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: Fall to the base Earth, from the Firmament:

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: Thy Sunne sets weeping in the lowly West,

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: Witnessing Stormes to come, Woe, and Vnrest:

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: Thy Friends are fled, to wait vpon thy Foes,

lines.speaker: Sal.
lines.text: And crossely to thy good, all fortune goes.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Bring forth these men:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: {% italic: Bushie %} and {% italic: Greene %}, I will not vex your soules,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: (Since presently your soules must part your bodies)

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: With too much vrging your pernitious liues,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: For 'twere no charitie: yet to wash your blood

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: From off my hands, here in the view of men,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I will vnfold some causes of your deaths.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: You haue mis‑led a Prince, a Royall King,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: A happie Gentleman in Blood, and Lineaments,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: By you vnhappied, and disfigur'd cleane:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: You haue in manner with your sinfull houres

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Made a Diuorce betwixt his Queene and him,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Broke the possession of a Royall Bed,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And stayn'd the beautie of a faire Queenes Cheekes,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: With teares drawn her eyes, with your foule wrongs.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: My selfe a Prince, by fortune of my birth,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Neere to the King in blood, and neere in loue,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Till you did make him mis‑interprete me,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Haue stoopt my neck vnder your iniuries,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And sigh'd my English breath in forraine Clouds,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Eating the bitter bread of banishment:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: While you haue fed vpon my Seignories,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Dis‑park'd my Parkes, and fell'd my forrest Woods;

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: From mine owne Windowes torne my Household Coat,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Raz'd out my Impresse, leauing me no signe,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Saue mens opinions, and my liuing blood,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To shew the World I am a Gentleman.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: This, and much more, much more then twice all this,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Condemnes you to the death: see them deliuered ouer

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To execution, and the hand of death.

lines.speaker: Bushie.
lines.text: More welcome is the stroake of death to me,

lines.speaker: Bushie.
lines.text: Then {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} to England.

lines.speaker: Greene.
lines.text: My comfort is, that Heauen will take our soules,

lines.speaker: Greene.
lines.text: And plague Iniustice with the paines of Hell.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: My Lord {% italic: Northemberland %} see them dispatch'd:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Vnckle, you say the Queene is at your House,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: For Heauens sake fairely let her be entreated,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Tell her I send to her my kind commends;

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Take speciall care my Greetings be deliuer'd.

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: A Gentleman of mine I haue dispatch'd

lines.speaker: York.
lines.text: With Letters of your loue, to her at large.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Thankes gentle Vnckle: come Lords away,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To fight with {% italic: Glendoure %}, and his Complices;

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: A while to worke, and after holliday.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Barkloughly Castle call you this at hand?

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: Yea, my Lord: how brooks your Grace the ayre,

lines.speaker: Au.
lines.text: After your late tossing on the breaking Seas?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Needs must I like it well: I weepe for ioy

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To stand vpon my Kingdome once againe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Deere Earth, I doe salute thee with my hand,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Though Rebels wound thee with their Horses hoofes:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As a long parted Mother with her Child,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Playes fondly with her teares, and smiles in meeting;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So weeping, smiling, greet I thee my Earth,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: and doe thee fauor with my Royall hands.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Feed not thy Soueraignes Foe, my gentle Earth,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nor with thy Sweetes, comfort his rauenous sence:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But let thy Spiders, that suck vp thy Venome,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And heauie‑gated Toades lye in their way,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Doing annoyance to the trecherous feete,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which with vsurping steps doe trample thee.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Yeeld stinging Nettles to mine Enemies;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And when they from thy Bosome pluck a Flower,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Guard it I prethee with a lurking Adder,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Whose double tongue may with a mortall touch

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Throw death vpon thy Soueraignes Enemies.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Mock not my sencelesse Coniuration, Lords;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: This Earth shall haue a feeling, and these Stones

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Proue armed Souldiers, ere her Natiue King

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall falter vnder foule Rebellious Armes.

lines.speaker: Car.
lines.text: Feare not my Lord, that Power that made you King

lines.speaker: Car.
lines.text: Hath power to keepe you King, in spight of all.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: He meanes, my Lord, tht we are too remisse,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Whilest {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} through our securitie,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Growes strong and great, in substance and in friends.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Discomfortable Cousin, knowest thou not,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That which the searching Eye of Heauen is hid

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Behind the Globe, that lights the lower World,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then Theeues and Robbers raunge abroad vnseene,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: In murthers and in Out‑rage bloody here:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But when from vnder this Terrestriall Ball

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He fires the prowd tops of the Easterne Pines,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And darts his Lightning through eu'ry guiltie hole,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Murthers, Treasons, and detested sinnes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: (The Cloake of Night being pluckt from off their backs)

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Stand bare and naked, trembling at themselues.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So when this Theefe, this Traytor {% italic: Bullingbrooke %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Who all this while hath reuell'd in the Night,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall see vs rising in our Throne, the East,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: His Treasons will sit blushing in his face,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Not able to endure the sight of Day:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But selfe‑affrighted, tremble at his sinne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Not all the Water in the rough rude Sea

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Can wash the Balme from an anoynted King;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The breath of worldly men cannot depose

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Deputie elected by the Lord:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For euery man that {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} hath prest,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To lift shrewd Steele against our Golden Crowne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Heauen for his {% italic: Richard %} hath in heauenly pay

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A glorious Angell: then if Angels fight,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Weake men must fall, for Heauen still guards the right.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Welcome my Lord, how farre off lyes your Power?

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: Nor neere, nor farther off, my gracious Lord,

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: Then this weake arme; discomfort guides my tongue,

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: And bids me speake of nothing but despaire:

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: One day too late, I feare (my Noble Lord)

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: Hath clouded all thy happie dayes on Earth:

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: Oh call backe Yesterday, bid Time returne,

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: And thou shalt haue twelue thousand fighting men:

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: To day, to day, vnhappie day too late

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: Orethrowes thy Ioyes, Friends, Fortune, and thy State;

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: For all the Welchmen hearing thou wert dead,

lines.speaker: Salisb.
lines.text: Are gone to {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}, disperst, and fled.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Comfort my Liege, why lookes your Grace so

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But now the blood of twentie thousand men

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Did triumph in my face, and they are fled,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And till so much blood thither come againe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Haue I not reason to looke pale, and dead?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: All Soules that will be safe, flye from my side,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For Time hath set a blot vpon my pride.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Comfort my Liege, remember who you are.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I had forgot my selfe. Am I not King?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Awake thou sluggard Maiestie, thou sleepest:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is not the Kings Name fortie thousand Names?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Arme, arme my Name: a punie subiect strikes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: At thy great glory. Looke not to the ground,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ye Fauorites of a King: are wee not high?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: High be our thoughts: I know my Vnckle {% italic: Yorke %}

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Hath Power enough to serue our turne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But who comes here?

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: More health and happinesse betide my Liege,

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Then can my care‑tun'd tongue deliuer him.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Mine eare is open, and my heart prepar'd:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The worst is worldly losse, thou canst vnfold:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Say, Is my Kingdome lost? Why 'twas my Care:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And what losse is it to be rid of Care?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Striues {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} to be as Great as wee?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Greater he shall not be: If hee serue God,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Wee'l serue him too, and be his Fellow so.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Reuolt our Subiects? That we cannot mend,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: They breake their Faith to God, as well as vs:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Cry Woe, Destruction, Ruine, Losse, Decay,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The worst is Death, and Death will haue his day.

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Glad am I, that your Highnesse is so arm'd

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: To beare the tidings of Calamitie.

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Like an vnseasonable stormie day,

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Which make the Siluer Riuers drowne their Shores,

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: As if the World were all dissolu'd to teares:

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: So {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}, couering your fearefull Land

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: With hard bright Steele, and hearts harder then Steele:

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: White Beares haue arm'd their thin and hairelesse Scalps

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Against thy Maiestie and Boyes with Womens Voyces,

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Striue to speake bigge, and clap their female ioints

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: In stiffe unwieldie Armes: against thy Crowne

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: They very Beads‑men learne to bend their Bowes

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Of double fatall Eugh: against thy State

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Yea Distaffe‑Women manage rustie Bills:

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Against thy Seat both young and old rebell,

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: And all goes worse then I haue power to tell.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Too well, too well thou tell'st a Tale so ill.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where is the Earle of Wiltshire? where is {% italic: Bagot %}?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What is become of {% italic: Bushie %}? where is {% italic: Greene %}?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That they haue let the dangerous Enemie

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Measure our Confines with such peacefull steps?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If we preuaile, their heads shall pay for it.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I warrant they haue made peace with {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}.

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Peace haue they made with him indeede (my

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Oh Villains, Vipers, damn'd without redemption,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Doggers, easily woon to fawne on any man,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Snakes in my heart blood warm'd, that sting my heart,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Three Iudasses, each one thrice worse then {% italic: Iudas %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Would they make peace? terrible Hell make warre

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vpon their spotted Soules for this Offence.

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Sweet Loue (I see) changing his propertie,

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Turnes to the sowrest, and most deadly hate:

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Againe vncurse their Soules; their peace is made

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: With Heads, and not with Hands: those whom you curse

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: Haue felt the worst of Deaths destroying hand,

lines.speaker: Scroope.
lines.text: And lye full low, grau'd in the hollow ground.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Is {% italic: Bushie, Greene %}, and the Earle of Wiltshire

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And tell sad stories of the death of Kings:

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That rounds the mortall Temples of a King,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Keepes Death his Court, and there the Antique sits

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Scoffing his State, and grinning at his Pompe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Allowing him a breath, a little Scene,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To Monarchize, be fear'd, and kill with lookes,

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As if this Flesh, which walls about our Life,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Were Brasse impregnable: and humor'd thus,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Comes at the last, and with a little Pinne

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Bores though his Castle Walls, and farwell King.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Couer your heads, and mock not flesh and blood

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With solemne Reuerence: throw away Respect,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tradition, Forme, and Ceremonious dutie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For you haue but mistooke me all this while:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I liue with Bread like you, feele Want,

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: to feare the Foe, since feare oppresseth strength,

lines.speaker: Carl.

lines.speaker: Carl.
