lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What sport shall we deuise here in this Garden,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To driue away the heauie thought of Care?

lines.speaker: La.
lines.text: Madame, wee'le play at Bowles.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: 'Twill make me thinke the World is full of Rubs,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And that my fortune runnes against the Byas.

lines.speaker: La.
lines.text: Madame, wee'le Dance.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My Legges can keepe no measure in Delight,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: When my poore Heart no measure keepes in Griefe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Therefore no Dancing (Girle) some other sport.

lines.speaker: La.
lines.text: Madame, wee'le tell Tales.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Of Sorrow, or of Griefe?

lines.speaker: La.
lines.text: Of eyther, Madame.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Of neyther, Girle.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: For if of Ioy, being altogether wanting,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: It doth remember me the more of Sorrow;

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Or if of Griefe, being altogether had,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: It addes more Sorrow to my want of Ioy:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: For what I haue, I need not to repeat;

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And what I want, it bootes not to complaine.

lines.speaker: La.
lines.text: Madame, Ile sing.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: 'Tis well that thou hast cause:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But thou should'st please me better, would'st thou weepe.

lines.speaker: La.
lines.text: I could weepe, Madame, would it doe you good.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And I could sing, would weeping doe me good,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And neuer borrow any Teare of thee.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But stay, here comes the Gardiners,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Let's step into the shadow of these Trees.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My wretchednesse, vnto a Rowe of Pinnes,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: They'le talke of State: for euery one doth so,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Against a Change; Woe is fore‑runne with Woe.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Goe binde thou vp yond dangling Apricocks,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Which like vnruly Children, make their Syre

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Stoupe with oppression of their prodigall weight:

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Giue some supportance to the bending twigges.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Goe thou, and like an Executioner

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Cut off the heads of too fast growing sprayes,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: That looke too loftie in our Common‑wealth:

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: All must be euen, in our Gouernment.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: You thus imploy'd, I will goe root away

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: The noysome Weedes, that without profit sucke

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: The Soyles fertilitie from wholesome flowers.

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: Why should we, in the compasse of a Pale,

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: Keepe Law and Forme, and due Proportion,

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: Shewing as in a Modell our firme Estate?

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: When our Sea‑walled Garden, the whole Land,

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: Is full of Weedes, her fairest Flowers choakt vp,

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: Her Fruit‑trees all vnpruin'd, her Hedges ruin'd,

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: Her Knots disorder'd, and her wholesome Hearbes

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: Swarming with Caterpillers.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Hold thy peace.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: He that hath suffer'd this disorder'd Spring,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Hath now himselfe met with the Fall of Leafe.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: The Weeds that his broad‑spreading Leaues did shelter,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: That seem'd, in eating him, to hold him vp,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Are pull'd vp, Root and all, by {% italic: Bullingbrooke: %}

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: I meane, the Earle of Wiltshire, {% italic: Bushie, Greene %}.

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: What are they dead?

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: They are,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: And {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} hath seiz'd the wastefull King.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Oh, what pitty is it, that he had not so trim'd

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: And drest his Land, as we this Garden, at time of yeare,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: And wound the Barke, the skin of our Fruit‑trees,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Least being ouer‑proud with Sap and Blood,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: With too much riches it confound it selfe?

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Had he done so, to great and growing men,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: They might haue liu'd to beare, and he to taste

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Their fruites of dutie. Superfluous branches

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: We lop away, that bearing boughes may liue:

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Had he done so, himselfe had borne the Crowne,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Which waste and idle houres, hath quite thrown downe.

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: What thinke you the King shall be depos'd?

lines.speaker: Gar.
lines.text: Deprest he is already, and depos'd

lines.speaker: Gar.
lines.text: 'Tis doubted he will be. Letters came last night

lines.speaker: Gar.
lines.text: To a deere Friend of the Duke of Yorkes,

lines.speaker: Gar.
lines.text: That tell blacke tydings.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Oh I am prest to death through want of speaking:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thou old {% italic: Adams %} likenesse, set to dresse this Garden:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this vnpleasing ( newes

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What Eue? what Serpent hath suggested thee,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To make a second fall of cursed man?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Why do'st thou say, King {% italic: Richard %} is depos'd,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Dar'st thou, thou little better thing then earth,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Diuine his downfall? Say, where, when, and how

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Cam'st thou by this ill‑tydings? Speake thou wretch.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Pardon me Madam. Little ioy haue I

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: To breath these newes; yet what I say, is true;

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: King {% italic: Richard %}, he is in the mighty hold

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Of {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}, their Fortunes both are weigh'd:

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: In your Lords Scale, is nothing but himselfe,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: And some few Vanities, that make him light:

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: But in the Ballance of great {% italic: Bullingbrooke %},

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Besides himselfe, are all the English Peeres,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: And with that oddes he weighes King {% italic: Richard %} downe.

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: Poste you to London, and you'l finde it so,

lines.speaker: Gard.
lines.text: I speake no more, then euery one doth know.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Nimble mischance, that art so light of foote,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Doth not thy Embassage belong to me?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And am I last that knowes it? Oh thou think'st

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To serue me last, that I may longest keepe

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thy sorrow in my breast. Come Ladies goe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To meet at London, Londons King in woe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What was I borne to this: that my sad looke,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Should grace the Triumph of great {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Gard'ner, for telling me this newes of woe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: I would the Plants thou graft'st, may neuer grow.

lines.speaker: G
lines.text: Poore Queen, so that thy State might be no worse,

lines.speaker: G
lines.text: I would my skill were subiect to thy curse:

lines.speaker: G
lines.text: Heere did she drop a teare, heere in this place

lines.speaker: G
lines.text: Ile set a Banke of Rew, sowre Herbe of Grace:

lines.speaker: G
lines.text: Rue, eu'n for ruth, heere shortly shall be seene,

lines.speaker: G
lines.text: In the remembrance of a Weeping Queene.

lines.speaker: Bullingbrooke.
lines.text: Call forth {% italic: Bagot %}.

lines.speaker: Bullingbrooke.
lines.text: Now {% italic: Bagot %}, freely speake thy minde,

lines.speaker: Bullingbrooke.
lines.text: What thou do'st know of Noble Glousters death:

lines.speaker: Bullingbrooke.
lines.text: Who wrought it with the King, and who perform'd

lines.speaker: Bullingbrooke.
lines.text: The bloody Office of his Timelesse end.

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: Then set before my face, the Lord {% italic: Aumerle %}.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Cosin, stand forth, and looke vpon that man.

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: My Lord {% italic: Aumerle %}, I know your daring tongue

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: Scornes to vnsay, what it hath once deliuer'd.

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: In that dead time, when Glousters death was plotted,

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: I heard you say, Is not my arme of length,

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: That reacheth from the restfull English Court

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: As farre as Callis, to my Vnkles head.

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: Amongst much other talke, that very time,

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: I heard you say, that you had rather refuse

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: The offer of an hundred thousand Crownes,

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: Then {% italic: Bullingbrookes %} returne to England; adding withall,

lines.speaker: Bag.
lines.text: How blest this Land would be, in this your Cosins death.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Princes, and Noble Lords:

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: What answer shall I make to this base man?

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Shall I so much dishonor my faire Starres,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: On equall termes to giue him chasticement?

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Either I must, or haue mine honor soyl'd

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: With th'Attaindor of his sland'rous Lippes.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: There is my Gage, the manuall Seale of death

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: That markes thee out for Hell. Thou lyest,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: And will maintaine what thou hast said, is false,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: In thy heart blood, though being all too base

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: To staine the temper of my Knightly sword.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: {% italic: Bagot %} forbeare, thou shalt not take it vp.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Excepting one, I would he were the best

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: In all this presence, that hath mou'd me so.

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: If that thy valour stand on sympathize:

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: There is my Gage, {% italic: Aumerle %}, in Gage to thine:

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: By that faire Sunne, that shewes me where thou stand'st,

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: I heard thee say (and vauntingly thou spak'st it)

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: That thou wer't cause of Noble Glousters death.

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: If thou deniest it, twenty times thou lyest,

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: And I will turne thy falshood to thy hart,

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: Where it was forged with my Rapiers point.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Thou dar'st not (Coward) liue to see the day.

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: Now by my Soule, I would it were this houre.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: {% italic: Fitzwater %} thou art damn'd to hell for this.

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: {% italic: Aumerle %}, thou lye'st: his Honor is as true

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: In this Appeale, as thou art all vniust:

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: And that thou art so, there I throw my Gage

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: To proue it on thee, to th'extreamest point

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: Of mortall breathing. Seize it, if thou dar'st.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: And if I do not, may my hands rot off,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: And neuer brandish more reuengefull Steele,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Ouer the glittering Helmet of my Foe.

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: My Lord {% italic: Fitz water %}:

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: I do remember well, the very time

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: {% italic: Aumerle %}, and you did talke.

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: My Lord,

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: 'Tis very true: You were in presence then,

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: And you can witnesse with me, this is true.

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: As false, by heauen,

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: As Heauen it selfe is true.

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: Surrey, thou Lyest.

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: Dishonourable Boy;

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: That Lye, shall lie so heauy on my Sword,

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: That it shall render Vengeance, and Reuenge,

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: Till thou the Lye‑giuer, and that Lye, doe lye

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: In earth as quiet, as thy Fathers Scull.

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: In proofe whereof, there is mine Honors pawne,

lines.speaker: Surrey.
lines.text: Engage it to the Triall, if thou dar'st.

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: How fondly do'st thou spurre a forward Horse?

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: If I dare eate, or drinke, or breathe, or liue,

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: I dare meete {% italic: Surrey %} in a Wildernesse,

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: And spit vpon him, whilest I say he Lyes,

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: And Lyes, and Lyes: there is my Bond of Faith,

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: To tye thee to my strong Correction.

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: As I intend to thriue in this new World,

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: {% italic: Aumerle %} is guiltie of my true Appeale.

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: Besides, I heard the banish'd {% italic: Norfolke %} say,

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: That thou {% italic: Aumerle %} didst send two of thy men,

lines.speaker: Fitzw.
lines.text: To execute the Noble Duke at Callis.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: Some honest Christian trust me with a Gage,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: That {% italic: Norfolke %} lyes: here doe I throw downe this,

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: If he may be repeal'd, to trie his Honor.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: These differences shall all rest vnder Gage,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Till {% italic: Norfolke %} be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be;

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And (though mine Enemie) restor'd againe

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To all his Lands and Seignories: when hee's return'd,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Against {% italic: Aumerle %} we will enforce his Tryall.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: That honorable day shall ne're be seene.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Many a time hath banish'd {% italic: Norfolke %} fought

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: For Iesu Christ, in glorious Christian field

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Streaming the Ensigne of the Christian Crosse,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Against black Pagans, Turkes, and Saracens:

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: And toyl'd with workes of Warre, retyr'd himselfe

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: To Italy, and there at Venice gaue

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: His Body to that pleasant Countries Earth,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: And his pure Soule vnto his Captaine Christ,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Vnder whose Colours he had fought so long.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Why Bishop, is {% italic: Norfolke %} dead?

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: As sure as I liue, my Lord.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Sweet peace conduct his sweet Soule

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: To the Bosome of good old {% italic: Abraham %}.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Lords Appealants, your shal all rest vnder gage,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Till we assigne you to your dayes of Tryall.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Great Duke of Lancaster, I come to thee

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: From plume‑pluckt {% italic: Richard %}, who with willing Soule

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Adopts thee Heire, and his high Scepter yeelds

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: To the possession of thy Royall Hand.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Ascend his Throne, descending now from him,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And long liue {% italic: Henry %}, of that Name the Fourth.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: In Gods Name, Ile ascend the Regall Throne.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Mary, Heauen forbid.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Worst in this Royall Presence may I speake,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Yet best beseeming me to speake the truth.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Would God, that any in this Noble Presence

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Were enough Noble, to be vpright Iudge

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Of Noble {% italic: Richard: %} then true Noblenesse would

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Learne him forbearance from so foule a Wrong.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: What Subiect can giue Sentence on his King?

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: And who sits here, that is not {% italic: Richards %} Subiect?

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Theeues are not iudg'd, but they are by to heare,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Although apparant guilt be seene in them:

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: And shall the figure of Gods Maiestie,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: His Captaine, Steward, Deputie elect,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Anoynted, Crown'd, planted many yeeres,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Be iudg'd by subiect, and inferior breathe,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: And he himselfe not present? Oh, forbid it, God,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: That in a Christian Climate, Soules refin'de

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Should shew so heynous, black, obscene a deed.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: I speake to Subiects, and a Subiect speakes,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Stirr'd vp by Heauen, thus boldly for his King.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: My Lord of Hereford here, whom you call King,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Is a foule Traytor to prowd {% italic: Herefords %} King.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: And if you Crowne him, let me prophecie,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: The blood of English shall manure the ground,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: And future Ages groane for his foule Act.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Peace shall goe sleepe with Turkes and Infidels,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: And in this Seat of Peace, tumultuous Warres

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Shall Kinne with Kinne, and Kinde with Kinde confound.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Disorder, Horror, Feare, and Mutinie

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Shall here inhabite, and this Land be call'd

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: The field of Golgotha, and dead mens Sculls.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Oh, if you reare this House, against this House

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: It will the wofullest Diuision proue,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: That euer fell vpon this cursed Earth.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Preuent it, resist it, and let it not be so,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Least Child, Childs Children cry against you, Woe.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Well haue you argu'd Sir: and for your paines,

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Of Capitall Treason we arrest you here.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: My Lord of Westminster, be it your charge,

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: To keepe him safely, till his day of Tryall.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: May it please you, Lords, to grant the Commons Suit?

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Fetch hither {% italic: Richard %}, that in common view

lines.text: He may surrender: so we shall proceede

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Without suspition.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: I will be his Conduct.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Lords, you that here are vnder our Arrest,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Procure your Sureties for your Dayes of Answer:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Little are we beholding to your Loue,

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: And little look'd for at your helping Hands.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Alack, why am I sent for to a King,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Before I haue shooke off the Regall thoughts

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet haue learn'd

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To insinuate, flatter, bowe, and bend my Knee.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Giue Sorrow leaue a while, to tuture me

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To this submission. Yet I well remember

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The fauors of these men: were they not mine?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Did they not sometime cry, All hayle to me?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So {% italic: Iudas %} did to Christ: but he in twelue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Found truth in all, but one; I, in twelue thousand, none.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: God saue the King: will no man say, Amen?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Am I both Priest, and Clarke? well then, Amen.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: God saue the King, although I be not hee:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And yet Amen, if Heauen doe thinke him mee.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To doe what seruice, am I sent for hither?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: To doe that office of thine owne good will,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Which tyred Maiestie did make thee offer:

lines.speaker: Yorke.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: To {% italic: Henry Bullingbrooke %}.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Giue me the Crown. Here Cousin, seize yͤ Crown:

lines.text: Here Cousin, on this side my Hand, on that side thine.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now is this Golden Crowne like a deepe Well,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That owes two Buckets, filling one another,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The emptier euer dancing in the ayre,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The other downe, vnseene, and full of Water:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That Bucket downe, and full of Teares am I,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Drinking my Griefes, whil'st you mount vp on high.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: I thought you had been willing to resigne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Crowne I am, but still my Griefes are mine:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: You may my Glories and my State depose,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But not my Griefes; still am I King of those.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Part of your Cares you giue me with your Crowne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your Cares set vp, do not pluck my Cares downe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Care, is losse of Care, by old Care done,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Your Care, is gaine of Care, by new Care wonne:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Cares I giue, I haue, though giuen away,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: They 'tend the Crowne, yet still with me they stay:

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Are you contented to resigne the Crowne?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, no; no, I: for I must nothing bee:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Therefore no, no, for I resigne to thee.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now, marke me how I will vndoe my selfe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I giue this heauie Weight from off my Head,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And this vnwieldie Scepter from my Hand,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The pride of Kingly sway from out my Heart.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With mine owne Teares I wash away my Balme,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With mine owne Hands I giue away my Crowne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With mine owne Tongue denie my Sacred State,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With mine owne Breath release all dutious Oathes;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: All Pompe and Maiestie I doe forsweare:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Manors, Rents, Reuenues, I forgoe;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Acts, Decrees, and Statutes I denie:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: God pardon all Oathes that are broke to mee,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: God keepe all Vowes vnbroke are made to thee.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Make me, that nothing haue, with nothing grieu'd,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And thou with all pleas'd, that hast all atchieu'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Long may'st thou liue in {% italic: Richards %} Seat to sit,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And soone lye {% italic: Richard %} in an Earthie Pit.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: God saue King {% italic: Henry %}, vn‑King'd {% italic: Richard %} sayes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And send him many yeeres of Sunne‑shine dayes.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What more remaines?

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: No more: but that you reade

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: These Accusations, and these grieuous Crymes,

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Committed by your Person, and your followers,

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Against the State, and Profit of this Land:

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: That by confessing them, the Soules of men

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: May deeme, that you are worthily depos'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Must I doe so ? and must I rauell out

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My weau'd‑vp follyes? Gentle {% italic: Northumberland %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If thy Offences were vpon Record,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Would it not shame thee, in so faire a troupe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To reade a Lecture of them? If thou would'st,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: There should'st thou finde one heynous Article,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Contayning the deposing of a King,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And cracking the strong Warrant of an Oath,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Mark'd with a Blot, damn'd in the Booke of Heauen.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nay, all of you, that stand and looke vpon me,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Whil'st that my wretchednesse doth bait my selfe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Though some of you, with {% italic: Pilate %}, wash your hands,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shewing an outward pittie: yet you {% italic: Pilates %}

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Haue here deliuer'd me to my sowre Crosse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And Water cannot wash away your sinne.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: My Lord dispatch, reade o're these Articles.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Mine Eyes are full of Teares, I cannot see:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And yet salt‑Water blindes them not so much,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But they can see a sort of Traytors here.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nay, if I turne mine Eyes vpon my selfe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I finde my selfe a Traytor with the rest:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For I haue giuen here my Soules consent,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: T'vndeck the pompous Body of a King;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Made Glory base; a Soueraigntie, a Slaue;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Prowd Maiestie, a Subiect; State, a Pesant.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: My Lord.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: No Lord of thine, thou haught‑insulting man;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: No, nor no mans Lord: I haue no Name, no Title;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: No, not that Name was giuen me at the Font,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But 'tis vsurpt: alack the heauie day,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That I haue worne so many Winters out,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And know not now, what Name to call my selfe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Oh, that I were a Mockerie, King of Snow,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Standing before the Sunne of {% italic: Bullingbrooke %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To melt my selfe away in Water‑drops.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Good King, great King, and yet not greatly good,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And if my word be Sterling yet in England,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let it command a Mirror hither straight,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That it may shew me what a Face I haue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Since it is Bankrupt of his Maiestie.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Goe some of you, and fetch a Looking‑Glasse.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Read o're this Paper, while yͤ Glasse doth come.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Fiend, thou torments me, ere I come to Hell.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Vrge it no more, my Lord {% italic: Northumberland %}.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: The Commons will not then be satisfy'd.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: They shall be satisfy'd: Ile reade enough,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: When I doe see the very Booke indeede,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where all my sinnes are writ, and that's my selfe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Giue me that Glasse, and therein will I reade.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: No deeper wrinckles yet? hath Sorrow strucke

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So may Blowes vpon this Face of mine,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And made no deeper Wounds ? Oh flatt'ring Glasse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Like to my followers in prosperitie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thou do'st beguile me. Was this Face, the Face

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That euery day, vnder his House‑hold Roofe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Did keepe ten thousand men? Was this the Face,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That like the Sunne, did make beholders winke?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is this the Face, which fac'd so many follyes,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That was at last out‑fac'd by {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A brittle Glory shineth in this Face,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As brittle as the Glory, is the Face,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For there it is, crackt in an hundred shiuers.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Marke silent King, the Morall of this sport,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How soone my Sorrow hath destroy'd my Face.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: The shadow of your Sorrow hath destroy'd

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: The shadow of your Face.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Say that againe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The shadow of my Sorrow: ha, let's see,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: 'Tis very true, my Griefe lyes all within,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And these externall manner of Laments,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Are meerely shadowes, to the vnseen Griefe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That swells with silence in the tortur'd Soule.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: There lyes the substance: and I thanke thee King

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For thy great bountie, that not onely giu'st

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Me cause to wayle, but teachest me the way

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How to lament the cause. Ile begge one Boone,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And then be gone, and trouble you no more.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall I obtaine it?

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Name it, faire Cousin.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Faire Cousin? I am greater then a King:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For when I was a King, my flatterers

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Were then but subiects; being now a subiect,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I haue a King here to my flatterer:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Being so great, I haue no neede to begge.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Yet aske.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And shall I haue?

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: You shall.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then giue me leaue to goe.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Whither?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Whither you will, so I were from your sights.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Goe some of you, conuey him to the Tower.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Oh good: conuey: Conueyers are you all,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That rise thus nimbly by a true Kings fall.

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: On Wednesday next, we solemnly set downe

lines.speaker: Bull.
lines.text: Our Coronation: Lords, prepare your selues.

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: A wofull Pageant haue we here beheld.

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: The Woes to come, the Children yet vnborne,

lines.speaker: Carl.
lines.text: Shall feele this day as sharpe to them as Thorne.

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: You holy Clergie‑men, is there no Plot

lines.speaker: Aum.
lines.text: To rid the Realme of this pernicious Blot.

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: Before I freely speake my minde herein,

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: You shall not onely take the Sacrament,

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: To bury mine intents, but also to effect

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: What euer I shall happen to deuise.

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: I see your Browes are full of Discontent,

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: Your Heart of Sorrow, and your Eyes of Teares.

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: Come home with me to Supper, Ile lay a Plot

lines.speaker: Abbot.
lines.text: Shall shew vs all a merry day.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: This way the King will come: this is the way

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To {% italic: Iulius Cæsars %} ill‑erected Tower:

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To whose flint Bosome, my condemned Lord

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Is doom'd a Prisoner, by prowd {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Here let vs rest, if this rebellious Earth

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Haue any resting for her true Kings Queene.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: But soft, but see, or rather doe not see,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: My faire Rose wither: yet looke vp; behold,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That you in pittie may dissolue to dew,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And wash him fresh againe with true‑loue Teares.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Ah thou, the Modell where old Troy did stand,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Thou Mappe of Honor, thou King {% italic: Richards %} Tombe,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And not King {% italic: Richard: %} thou most beauteous Inne,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: When Triumph is become an Ale‑house Guest.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ioyne not with griefe, faire Woman, do not so,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To make my end too sudden: learne good Soule,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To thinke our former State a happie Dreame,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: From which awak'd, the truth of what we are,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shewes vs but this. I am sworne Brother (Sweet)

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To grim Necessitie; and hee and I

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Will keepe a League till Death. High thee to France,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And Cloyster thee in some Religious House:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Our holy liues must winne a new Worlds Crowne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which our prophane houres here haue stricken downe.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: What, is my {% italic: Richard %} both in shape and minde

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Transform'd, and weaken'd? Hath {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Depos'd thine Intellect? hath he beene in thy Heart?

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: The Lyon dying, thrusteth forth his Paw,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And wounds the Earth, if nothing else, with rage

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To be o're‑powr'd: and wilt thou, Pupill‑like,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Take thy Correction mildly, kisse the Rodde,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And fawne on Rage with base Humilitie,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Which art a Lyon, and a King of Beasts?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A King of Beasts indeed: if aught but Beasts,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I had beene still a happy King of Men.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Good (sometime Queene) prepare thee hence for France:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thinke I am dead, and that euen here thou tak'st,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As from my Death‑bed, my last liuing leaue.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: In Winters tedious Nights sit by the fire

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With good old folkes, and let them tell thee Tales

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of wofull Ages, long agoe betide:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And ere thou bid good‑night, to quit their griefe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Tell thou the lamentable fall of me,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And send the hearers weeping to their Beds:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For why? the sencelesse Brands will sympathize

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The heauie accent of thy mouing Tongue,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And in compassion, weepe the fire out:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And some will mourne in ashes, some coale‑black,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For the deposing of a rightfull King.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: My Lord, the mind of {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} is chang'd.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: You must to Pomfret, not vnto the Tower.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: And Madame, there is order ta'ne for you:

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: With all swift speed, you must away to France.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: {% italic: Northumberland %}, thou Ladder wherewithall

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The mounting {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} ascends my Throne,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The time shall not be many houres of age,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: More then it is, ere foule sinne, gathering head,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shall breake into corruption: thou shalt thinke,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Though he diuide the Realme, and giue thee halfe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: It is too little, helping him to all:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: He shall thinke, that thou which know'st the way

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To plant vnrightfully Kings, wilt know againe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Being ne're so little vrg'd another way,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To pluck him headlong from the vsurped Throne.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The Loue of wicked friends conuerts to Feare;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That Feare, to Hate; and Hate turnes one, or both,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To worthie Danger, and deserued Death.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: My guilt be on my Head, and there an end:

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: Take leaue, and part, for you must part forthwith.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Doubly diuorc'd? (bad men) ye violate

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A two‑fold Marriage; 'twixt my Crowne, and me,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And then betwixt me, and my marryed Wife.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Let me vn‑kisse the Oath 'twixt thee, and me;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And yet not so, for with a Kisse 'twas made.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Part vs, {% italic: Northumerland: %} I, towards the North,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where shiuering Cold and Sicknesse pines the Clyme:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Queene to France: from whence, set forth in pompe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: She came adorned hither like sweet May;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Sent back like Hollowmas, or short'st of day.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: And must we be diuided? must we part?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I, hand from hand (my Loue) and heart heart.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Banish vs both, and send the King with me.

lines.speaker: North.
lines.text: That were some Loue, but little Pollicy.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Then whither he goes, thither let me goe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So two together weeping, make one Woe.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Weepe thou for me in France; I, for thee heere:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Better farre off, then neere, be ne're the neere.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Goe, count thy Way with Sighes; I, mine with Groanes.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: So longest Way shall haue the longest Moanes.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Twice for one step Ile groane, yͤ Way being short,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And peece the Way out with a heauie heart.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Come, come, in wooing Sorrow let's be briefe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Since wedding it, there is such length in Griefe:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: One Kisse shall stop our mouthes, and dumbely part;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thus giue I mine, and thus take I thy heart.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: Giue me mine owne againe: 'twere no good part,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: To take on me to keep, and kill thy heart.

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: So, now I haue mine owne againe, be gone,

lines.speaker: Qu.
lines.text: That I may striue to kill it with a groane.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: We make Woe wanton with this fond delay:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Once more adieu; the rest, let Sorrow say.

lines.speaker: Duch.
lines.text: My Lord, you told me you would tell the rest,

lines.speaker: Duch.
lines.text: When weeping made you breake the story off,

lines.speaker: Duch.
lines.text: Of our two Cousins comming into London.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Where did I leaue?

lines.speaker: Duch.
lines.text: At that sad stoppe, my Lord,

lines.speaker: Duch.
lines.text: Where rude mis‑gouern'd hands, from Windowes tops,

lines.speaker: Duch.
lines.text: Threw dust and rubbish on King {% italic: Richards %} head.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Then, as I said, the Duke, great {% italic: Bullingbrooke %},

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Mounted vpon a hot and fierie Steed,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Which his aspiring Rider seem'd to know,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: With slow, but stately pace, kept on his course:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: While all tongues cride, God saue thee {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: You would haue thought the very windowes spake,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: So many greedy lookes of yong and old,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Through Casements darted their desiring eyes

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Vpon his visage: and that all the walles,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: With painted Imagery had said at once,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Iesu preserue thee, welcom {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}.

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Whil'st he, from one side to the other turning,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Bare‑headed, lower then his proud Steeds necke,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Bespake them thus: I thanke you Countrimen:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: And thus still doing, thus he past along.

lines.speaker: Dutch.
lines.text: Alas poore {% italic: Richard %}, where rides he the whilst?

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: As in a Theater, the eyes of men

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: After a well grac'd actor leaues the Stage,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Are idlely bent on him that enters next,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Thinking his prattle to be tedious:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Euen so, or with much more contempt, mens eyes

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Did scowle on {% italic: Richard %}: no man cride, God saue him:

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: No ioyfull tongue gaue him his welcome home,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: But dust was throwne vpon his Sacred head,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: Which with such gentle sorrow he shooke off,

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: His face still combating with teares and smiles

lines.speaker: Yorke.
lines.text: (The badges of his greefe and patience)

lines.speaker: Dut.

lines.text: Speake Pardon, as 'tis currant in our Land,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: I pardon him with all my hart.

lines.speaker: Dut.

lines.speaker: Bul.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: With all the rest of that consorted crew,

lines.text: Didst thou not marke the King what words hee

lines.text: Haue I no friend will rid me of this liuing feare:

lines.speaker: Ext.
lines.text: Was it not so?

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: Those were his very words.

lines.speaker: Ex.
lines.text: Haue I no Friend? (quoth he:) he spake it twice,

lines.speaker: Ex.
lines.text: And vrg'd it twice together, did he not?

lines.speaker: Ser.
lines.text: He did.

lines.speaker: Ex.
lines.text: And speaking it, he wistly look'd on me,

lines.speaker: Ex.
lines.text: As who should say, I would thou wer't the man

lines.speaker: Ex.
lines.text: That would diuorce this terror from my heart,

lines.speaker: Ex.
lines.text: Meaning the King at Pomfret: Come, let's goe;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I haue bin studying, how to compare

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: This Prison where I liue, vnto the World:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And for because the world is populous,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And heere is not a Creature, but my selfe,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I cannot do it: yet Ile hammer't out.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Braine, Ile proue the Female to my Soule,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Soule, the Father: and these two beget

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: A generation of still breeding Thoughts;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And these same Thoughts, people this Little World

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: In humors, like the people of this world,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For no thought is contented. The better sort,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: As thoughts of things Diuine, are intermixt

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With scruples, and do set the Faith it selfe

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Against the Faith: as thus: Come litle ones: & then again,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: It is as hard to come, as for a Camell

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To thred the posterne of a Needles eye.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thoughts tending to Ambition, they do plot

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Vnlikely wonders; how these vaine weake nailes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: May teare a passage through the Flinty ribbes

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of this hard world, my ragged prison walles:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And for they cannot, dye in their owne pride.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thoughts tending to Content, flatter themselues,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That they are not the first of Fortunes slaues,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nor shall not be the last. Like silly Beggars,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Who sitting in the Stockes, refuge their shame

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That many haue, and others must sit there;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And in this Thought, they finde a kind of ease,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Bearing their owne misfortune on the backe

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of such as haue before indur'd the like.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thus play I in one Prison, many people,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And none contented. Sometimes am I King;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Then Treason makes me wish my selfe a Beggar,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And so I am. Then crushing penurie,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Perswades me, I was better when a King:

lines.speaker: Rich.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thinke that I am vn‑king'd by {% italic: Bullingbrooke %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And straight am nothing. But what ere I am,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Nor I, nor any man, that but man is,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With nothing shall be pleas'd, till he be eas'd

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: With being nothing. Musicke do I heare?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Ha, ha? keepe time: How sowre sweet Musicke is,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: When Time is broke, and no Proportion kept?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So is it in the Musicke of mens liues:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And heere haue I the daintinesse of eare,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: To heare time broke in a disorder'd string:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: But for the Concord of my State and Time,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Had not an eare to heare my true Time broke.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: I wasted Time, and now doth Time waste me:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For now hath Time made me his numbring clocke;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: My Thoughts, are minutes; and with Sighes they iarre,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Their watches on vnto mine eyes, the outward Watch,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Whereto my finger, like a Dialls point,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is pointing still, in cleansing them from teares.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Now sir, the sound that tels what houre it is,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Are clamorous groanes, that strike vpon my heart,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Which is the bell: so Sighes, and Teares, and Grones,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Shew Minutes, Houres, and Times: but my Time

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Runs poasting on, in {% italic: Bullingbrookes %} proud ioy,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: While I stand fooling heere, his iacke o'th'Clocke.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: This Musicke mads me, let it sound no more,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For though it haue holpe madmen to their wits,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: In me it seemes, it will make wise‑men mad:

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Yet blessing on his heart that giues it me;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: For 'tis a signe of loue, and loue to {% italic: Richard %},

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Is a strange Brooch, in this all‑hating world.

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: Haile Royall Prince.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Thankes Noble Peere,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The cheapest of vs, is ten groates too deere.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: What are thou? And how com'st thou hither?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Where no man euer comes, but that sad dogge

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That brings me food, to make misfortune liue?

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: I was poore Groome of thy Stable (King)

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: When thou wer't King: who trauelling towards Yorke,

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: With much adoo, at length haue gotten leaue

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: To looke vpon my (sometimes Royall) masters face.

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: O how it yern'd my heart, when I beheld

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: In London streets, that Coronation day,

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: When {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} rode on Roane Barbary,

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: that horse, that thou so often hast bestrid,

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: That horse, that I so carefully haue drest.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Rode he on Barbary? Tell me gentle Friend,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: How went he vnder him?

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: So proudly, as if he had disdain'd the ground.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: So proud, that {% italic: Bullingbrooke %} was on his backe;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: That Iade hath eate bread from my Royall hand.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: This hand hath made him proud with clapping him.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Would he not stumble? Would he not fall downe

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: (Since Pride must haue a fall) and breake the necke

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Of that proud man, that did vsurpe his backe?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Forgiuenesse horse: Why do I raile on thee,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Since thou created to be aw'd by man

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Was't borne to beare? I was not made a horse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: And yet I beare a burthen like an Asse,

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Spur‑gall'd, and tyrd by iauncing {% italic: Bullingbrooke %}.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: Fellow, giue place, heere is no longer stay.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: If thou loue me, 'tis time thou wer't away.

lines.speaker: Groo.
lines.text: What my tongue dares not, that my heart shall

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: My Lord, wilt please you to fall too?

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Taste of it first, as thou wer't wont to doo.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: My Lord I dare not: Sir {% italic: Pierce %} of Exton,

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: Who lately came from th'King, commands the contrary.

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: The diuell take {% italic: Henrie %} of Lancaster, and thee;

lines.speaker: Rich.
lines.text: Patience is stale, and I am weary of it.

lines.speaker: Keep.
lines.text: Helpe, helpe, helpe.

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: How now? what meanes Death in this rude assalt?

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: Villaine, thine owne hand yeelds thy deaths instrument,

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: Go thou and fill another roome in hell.

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: That hand shall burne in neuer‑quenching fire,

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: That staggers thus my person. {% italic: Exton %}, thy fierce hand,

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: Hath with the Kings blood, stain'd the Kings own land.

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: Mount, mount my soule, thy seate is vp on high,

lines.speaker: Ri.
lines.text: Whil'st my grosse flesh sinkes downward, heere to dye.

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: As full of Valor, as of Royall blood,

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: Both haue I spilt: Oh would the deed were good.

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: For now the diuell, that told me I did well,

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: Sayes, that this deede is chronicled in hell.

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: This dead King to the liuing King Ile beare,

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: Take hence the rest, and giue them buriall heere.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Kinde Vnkle Yorke, the latest newes we heare,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Is that the Rebels haue consum'd with fire

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Our Towne of Ciceter in Gloucestershire,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: But whether they be tane or slaine, we heare not.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Welcome my Lord: What is the newes?

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: First to thy Sacred State, wish I all happinesse:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: The next newes is, I haue to London sent

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: The heads of {% italic: Salsbury, Spencer, Blunt %}, and {% italic: Kent %}:

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: The manner of their taking may appeare

lines.speaker: Nor.
lines.text: At large discoursed in this paper heere.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: We thank thee gentle {% italic: Percy %} for thy paines,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: And to thy worth will adde right worthy gaines.

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: My Lord, I haue from Oxford sent to London,

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: The heads of {% italic: Broccas %}, and Sir {% italic: Bennet Seely %},

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: Two of the dangerous consorted Traitors,

lines.speaker: Fitz.
lines.text: That sought at Oxford, thy dire ouerthrow.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Thy paines {% italic: Fitzwaters %} shall not be forgot,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Right Noble is thy merit, well I wot.

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: The grand Conspirator, Abbot of Westminster,

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: With clog of Conscience, and sowre Melancholly,

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: Hath yeelded vp his body to the graue:

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: But heere is {% italic: Carlile %}, liuing to abide

lines.speaker: Per.
lines.text: Thy Kingly doome, and sentence of his pride.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: {% italic: Carlile %}, this is your doome:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Choose out some secret place, some reuerend roome

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: More then thou hast, and with it ioy thy life:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: So as thou liu'st in peace, dye free from strife:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: For though mine enemy thou hast euer beene,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: High sparkes of Honor in thee haue I seene.

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: Great King, within this Coffin I present

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: Thy buried feare. Heerein all breathlesse lies

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: The mightiest of thy greatest enemies

lines.speaker: Exton.
lines.text: {% italic: Richard %} of Burdeaux, by me hither brought.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: {% italic: Exton %}, I thanke thee not, for thou hast wrought

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: A deede of Slaughter, with thy fatall hand,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Vpon my head, and all this famous Land.

lines.speaker: Ex.
lines.text: From your owne mouth my Lord, did I this deed.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: They loue not poyson, that do poyson neede,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Nor do I thee: though I did wish him dead,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: I hate the Murtherer, loue him murthered.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: The guilt of conscience take thou for thy labour,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: But neither my good word, nor Princely fauour.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: With {% italic: Caine %} go wander through the shade of night,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: And neuer shew thy head by day, nor light.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Lords, I protest my soule is full of woe,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: That blood should sprinkle me, to make me grow.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Come mourne with me, for that I do lament,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: And put on sullen Blacke incontinent:

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: Ile make a voyage to the Holy‑land,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: to wash this blood off from my guilty hand.

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: March sadly after, grace my mourning heere,

lines.speaker: Bul.
lines.text: In weeping after this vntimely Beere.
